title: top foreign office official apologises
story: Top Foreign Office official apologises for misleading MPs on Afghan animal evacuationBoris Johnson has been accused of lying over whether he authorised the airlt of cats and dogs from Afghanistan - but he branded claims total rhubarb Image: PAByLizzy BuchanDeputy Online Political Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |commentsA top Foreign Office official has apologised for misleading MPs over the controversial airlt of cats and dogs from Afghanistan.Sir Philip Barton admitted he had given inadvertently inaccurate answers when he told the Foreign Affairs Committee that Nigel Casey, the PMaposs special representative in Afghanistan, had not received any correspondence suggesting Boris Johnson authorised the evacuation of animals from the Nowzad charity.But leaked emails show Mr Casey asked an official to seek clear guidance for us from No asap on what they would like us to do in the case.Mr Johnson has been accused of lying over whether he intervened to help ex-marine Pen Farthing get the animals out of Kabul as the Taliban swept to power last August.The PM described the claims from a Foreign Office whistleblower as total rhubarb on Thursday, despite bombshell emails showing staff said he had authorised the move. The row casts fresh doubt on the PMaposs integrity as he waits for the results of Sue Grayaposs report into Downing Street parties. Sir Philip, the Foreign Officeaposs permanent under-secretary, initially told the committee that Mr Casey had not received any correspondence about the PMaposs involvement.But leaked emails, published by the BBC, show Mr Casey asked an official to seek clear guidance for us from No  asap on what they would like us to do in the case.Sir Philip has now written to the committeeaposs chairman Tom Tugendhat to apologise for giving inadvertently inaccurate answers. But he said that on the day the email was sent, Nigel was almost entirely focused, in his role as Gold in our crisis response, on the terrorist threat to the evacuation. Labouraposs Chris Bryant, who sits on the committee, said: “The disaster of our withdrawal from Afghanistan requires the highest level of scrutiny. Parliament can only do thisthere is transparency from Government. “Since we published internal Foreign Office emails earlier this week, further emails have come to light that make it dficult to have confidence that we are getting full answers from the department.” The chaotic withdrawal from Afghanistan last year is being scrutinised by the Foreign Affairs Committee amid ongoing questions about the Governmentaposs handling of the crisis.  Sir Philip was criticised when he admitted he had stayed on holiday for nearly two weeks after Kabul fell to the Taliban. The-then Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab also failed toimmediately from a family holiday in Crete. The evacuation of animals looked after by the Nowzad charity sparked a major controversy as thousands of people trying to flee the Taliban were left behind. Downing Street has repeatedly denied intervening to help Mr Farthing, who was able to evacuate  cats and dogs from the country using a plane funded by donations raised in a high profile campaign But an email shared with MPs by whistleblower Raphael Marshall showed a Foreign Office official saying that the Prime Minister had authorised the animalsapos rescue.And the BBC reported another email from the same day saying then-foreign secretary Dominic Raab was seeking a steer from No  on whether to call Nowzad staff forward.Another email from Mr Casey showed him asking a security official to seek clear guidance for us from No  asap on what they would like us to do.  The emails to the Commons inquiry were submitted by Mr Marshall, who worked for the Foreign Office at the time and alleges the animals were evacuated following an order from Mr Johnson.Commons Leader Jacob Rees-Mogg tried to downplay the dispute as fussing about a few animals.Downing Street sought to argue the officials in the first correspondence to be published may have been mistaken. The Prime Ministeraposs official spokesman said: Itaposs not uncommon in Whitehall for a decision to be interpreted or portrayed as coming directly from the Prime Minister even when thataposs not the case, and itaposs our understanding thataposs what happened in this instance. We appreciate it was a frenetic time for those officials dealing with this situation. Mr Farthing submitted a five-page statement defending his actions to the committee, saying the animals were transported in the hold of the plane which is not safe for humans. He said the charity had offered seats on the plane to British evacuees but their offer was turned down by the Government. title: 10 major changes made highway
story: major changes made to Highway Code from today which most drivers wont knowThe Highway Code contains advice and rules for people on Britain’s roads. The latest changes are advisory, so non-compliance will not result in a fine. A hierarchy of road users is also being introducedCyclists are advised to ride in the centre of lanes on quieter roads Image: Getty ImagesByNeil Lancefield:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments A major revamp of the Highway Code to boost protection for cyclists and pedestrians comes into force today amid concern millions of drivers are unaware of the changes.The new guidance means traffic should give way when pedestrians are crossing or waiting to cross at junctions. Cyclists are advised to ride in the centre of lanes on quieter roads, in slower-moving traffic, and when approaching junctions, to make themselves as visible as possible.A hierarchy of road users is also being introduced, meaning drivers will have more responsibility to watch out for people cycling, walking, or riding a horse, and cyclists will have more responsibility to be aware of pedestrians. Turning traffic should now give way when pedestrians are crossing or waiting to cross at junctions.  And motorists will be encouraged to adopt the so-called ‘Dutch Reach’, opening the door next to them with the opposite hand so they look over their shoulder, meaning they’re more likely to spot and less likely to injure passing cyclists and pedestrians. The Highway Code contains advice and rules for people on Britain’s roads. Nine sections have been updated, with  rules added or amended. The changes are advisory, so non-compliance will not result in a fine. AA president Edmund King expressed concern at the potential impact of the guidance to give way to pedestrians at junctions. He suggested that drivers are “likely to get hit by another vehicle from behind”they stop on dual carriageways or fast-flowing A roads to let someone cross. He also warned that pedestrians could be endangeredone vehicle gives way but another travelling in the opposite direction fails to stop.  “Drivers will have to make their own judgments on what they should do in the scenarios they find themselves in,” Mr King said. “However,the judgments of the driver and the pedestrian are at odds on a very busy road, this could lead to problems.” An AA survey of more than , drivers carried out earlier this month indicated that % were unaware of the changes. A communications drive will be launched by the Department for Transport’s road safety offshoot Think! in mid-February, with further activity later in the summer. Roads minister Baroness Vere said this week that the updated Highway Code will make Britain’s roads safer and encourage people to “respect and consider the needs of those around them”. Charity Cycling UK said the changes must be “communicated with simple, accurate and memorable messaging”.  of the major changes . Hierarchy of road users A new hierarchy means people in charge of vehicles that can cause the most harm in the event of a collision have the greatest responsibility to look out for other road users. . Walking, cycling or riding in shared spaces Cyclists should not overtake people walking or riding a horse in shared spaces closely or at high speed, while pedestrians should take care not to obstruct paths. . Positioning of cyclists Cyclists should make themselves as visible as possible by riding in the centre of lanes on quiet roads, in slower-moving traffic and at the approach to junctions. . Pedestrians crossing at junctions Turning traffic should give way when people are crossing or waiting to cross at junctions. Traffic must give way to people on zebra crossings. . Overtaking cyclists Drivers travelling at speeds of up to mph should leave at least . metres when overtaking cyclists. They should give more space when overtaking at higher speeds. . Opening car doors Car occupants should open doors using their hand on the opposite side to the door, making them turn their head to look over their shoulder. This technique, known as the Dutch Reach, reduces the chances of doors being opened into the path of cyclists and motorcyclists. . Overtaking cyclists at junctions When cyclists are going straight ahead at a junction, they have priority over traffic waiting to turn into or out of a side road, unless road signs or markings indicate otherwise. . Cycling in groups People cycling can ride two abreast but should be considerate of the needs of other road users when in groups. . Roundabouts Drivers should take extra care when entering roundabouts to make sure they do not cut across cyclists. . Electric vehicle charging Electric car owners using a public chargepoint should park near the device and avoid creating a trip hazard from trailing cables. title: boy could wait years treatment
story: Boy could wait years for treatment so he can walk because hes too ticklishConor Stapleton suffers from tight tendons which mean his feet point nearly perpendicular to the ground meaning he struggles to walk or stand up properlyJade Hatton and her -month-old Conor Stapleton Image: MEN MediaByHelena VestyKieren WilliamsNews Reporter:,  Jan |comments A young boy might be forced to “wait years” for treatment that will let him walk again because “he’s too ticklish”. Conor Stapleton has the bizarre condition where his feet point almost perpendicular to the ground all the time.This leaves the -month-old unable to walk properly.Worried mum Jade Hatton first spotted the issue when Conor was around -weeks-old, Manchester Evening News reported.She said that she was told by health visitors to monitor his mobility on two occasions, but in the nearly two years since she claims his situation has only grown more dire and left him unable to walk or even put on shoes. Jade, from Hyde in Greater Manchester, said: “[Doctors] checked him when he was born, but didn’t say anything. But when he was -weeks-old, I could tell there was something wrong with his feet.  “I said to the health visitor that his feet were pointed, the visitor said he was fine. “When he got to about nine months, they were questioning me why he wasn’t trying to walk, or stand against things to bend down and pick things up. “I said it was because of his feet. They said ‘wait until he’s one’, then ‘wait until he’s  months’. Growing ever more worried, the -year-old mum took her son to the GP. They confirmed Conor was suffering from tight tendons, meaning he can only perch on his toes for a brief amount of time.  After already being referred to one hospital, the mum says she then had to aposwait months for an appointmentapos to see a specialist at a second hospital. She added: “Then in June last year, I went to the doctor again who said it was tight tendons, it took them ages to get me an appointment. “I went to Tameside Hospital, where the doctor said it was tight tendons, I then had to wait two, three months for an appointment at the Royal Manchester Childrenaposs Hospital. When Jade and Conor finally reached the doctor who would be putting casts on his feet in order to begin to correct his standing, the family were told he was apostoo ticklishapos, claims Jade. The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Now, she says she has been referred back to Tameside, leaving her confused. Jade continued: “I went on January , took him in. The [doctor] sat down, she felt his feet and said ‘he’s too ticklish - to make my job easier, I’m not going to put his cast on today, I’m going to wait until he’s older and know why he’s having it done’. “Those were the doctor’s actual words. That appointment was specically for him to have his casts on because he can’t wear shoes, it’s a struggle putting his socks on. He can’t do anything at all. Not only are Conoraposs pointed feet giving him trouble learning to walk, there are other huge development impacts, adds the mum. “It’s made him extremely clingy to me, said Jade. Even when I take him to playgroups, he won’t go over to other children, and they won’t come over to him because he’s crawling. “So he can’t interact or play with them. “When he’s standing against the couch, he’s flopping back down and hurting his leg or banging his head. He’s learned to walk on his knees, and they’re getting bruised. “He just stays at home most of the time, playing with his cars or reading his books because that’s all he can do. “I wanted to take him to nursery, but he won’t be able to do things children his age do because they go out at playtime or go for walks in the woods. He would have to be in a pram. “And he’s getting that stressed and upset now because he can’t get about, he’s starting to have bad mood swings. “If he wants to climb on something and I don’t have the time to pick him up straight away, he’ll scream because he can’t get up on his own yet because of his feet.A complaint has been lodged with the NHS apos Patient Advice and Liaison Serviceby the mum, but she says she fears it could be aposyearsapos before Conor gets his casts - as delays to treatments across the health system continue in the wake of the pandemic. “I feel like screaming because I’ve been saying this since he was -weeks-old. I think people feel like it’s not a big deal because he’s not theirs, they don’t have to deal with him getting stressed and upset. “I rang PALS to complain and they came back to me saying they wanted a doctor to go over his feet again for the third time, she says. “The PALS staff member told me thatI didn’t hear back in a week, to let them know. It’s been about two-and-a-half weeks and I’ve heard nothing back. “It just feels like I’m not being listened to. He really needs casts to help him because his feet are so pointed. “My friend’s kids, who are even younger than him, who are walking, he can’t do anything like that. It puts a knot in my chest because he can’t walk, he can’t play. “I’ve been trying my hardest since he was -weeks-old and I don’t know what to do anymore, I’m stuck.  Adding to her anxiety, Jade is pregnant again and cannot continue to pick Conor up to carry him around like she used to. “I’m also  weeks pregnant, says Jade. I can’t keep carrying him aroundhe needs to go somewhere, itaposs putting pressure on my stomach and back lting him up. Iaposve had miscarriages in the past. But he canapost have a regular bed, he needs a cot that I have to lt him out of, because he could roll out and not be able to get back up. My partner works nights so itaposs usually me there. Heaposs like a baby thataposs as heavy as a toddler. I feel like Iaposm on my own. A spokesperson for Manchester University Foundation Trust, which runs the Royal Manchester Childrenaposs Hospital, said: “Conor’s mother has been in touch with our Patient Advice and Liaison Service and they’ll be discussing his referrals and treatment with her directly.” Tameside and Glossop Integrated Care NHS Foundation Trust Fountain declined to comment. title: covid army veterans volunteers jabs
story: Jab volunteer Army veterans wise words for man having his first Covid vaccineFrom helping out at vaccination centres to using their valuable skills to help with logistics, veterans are playing a big part in the fight against Covid-If you haven’t already had your booster, now is the time to do itAdvertorialByDave MastersDigital Commercial Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan  As the Omicron iant continues to spread rapidly and more people book in their all-important vaccine booster, veterans, along with other volunteers, are doing vital work to help the NHS deliver the programme.Every adult in the country needs a booster dose, soyou haven’t already had yours, now is the time to do it.Just go to nhs.uk covidvaccination to book – and you can also make an appointment for --year-olds and help older teenagers get theirs too.Here we speak to some of the veterans about their work, starting with an ex-soldier who had two words for a man having his first jab which could inspire others to do the same... ‘Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer’ Working for the ambulance service, I saw the effects of Covid- during the first wave – almost every patient we took in was ill with the virus. I was part of the Re:Act Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. The NHS was under the cosh at the time and I was part of the RE:ACT Disaster Response team who stepped up to help. I helped build the Nightingale hospitals in Wales and also worked with the local council in Hereford to distribute PPE. Now I’m at the pop-up vaccination centre in Hereford. There are two of us here who are ex-military – the other guy is an ex-submariner so we’ve got a broad range of skills. There’s not a lot that comes across our path that bamboozles us.The first time I volunteered was on a day off from work. We were tasked with letting people know about the vaccination centre, but of course we didn’t want to browbeat them so we let people come to us. Initially people thought we were giving out lateral flow tests – we’d say, No, we’re here for boosters or your first or second vaccination. It was quiet for the first hour, but word obviously spread around Hereford and by the end of the day I’d say we’d vaccinated about  people, from schoolkids upwards. I think . per cent of people were happy to have a vaccination. I thought: Evenyou get five people vaccinated, that’s five people who won’t suffer.” Yes, you might catch it, but you’re much less likely to end up in hospital. When people ask meI think it works, I feel like I can provide the back story for them.We’ve now even had people come in for their first jabs. I asked one, What changed your mind  He said,Omicron, because it’s more infectious’. I just said, “Well done.”So while I don’t strong-arm people, I do tell them, “I think you should get vaccinated. ‘We all need the booster so that le can get back to normal’  I joined the Royal Air Force in  and my last posting was out in Cyprus, but I always wanted to transition to a career in the NHS. Back in October  I joined the East of England Covid- mass vaccination programme and my first role was to provide support in the planning and delivery of large-scale centres, hospital hubs and community pharmacies. Now I’m working as the children’s project manager, leading and coordinating plans. This involves collating, analysing and improving plans, reporting to the programme director and the national team, using my past experiences to collaborate, advise and implement processes.  I’m good at seeing a problem and thinking outside the box to solve it. I can get parachuted into a project within the Covid- programme and am able to run with it. Every day is dferent, but that doesn’t faze me. I’m very adaptable and flexible – and I’ll give  per cent to achieving the common goal. Working with other people from the Forces means there’s a great sense of camaraderie. We share the same service ethos. If there’s a deadline, we’ll just knuckle down and get the job done. This is not a - job. Even though I might have to get up at .am to jump on a work call, I have no problem with that. I was motivated to join the Covid- programme by my sense of duty, and I’m really proud to be part of it. I have a passion for helping people and making sure things are completed to the highest standard. This gives me a real sense of achievement. I like being able to make a dference. The public response to getting boosted has been great, but there is still a long way to go. I believe the Get Boosted Now campaign is so important because we need to protect ourselves, the vulnerable and the future generations. We also need to get everyone boosted so we can get le back to normal as soon as possible. ‘One of my ex-soldiers gave me the Covid- jab’  I was  when I joined the Navy as a medic. It was the year after the Falklands War and I thought I’d like to get involved in something for the service of the country – to do what’s necessary when the time comes. As a Navy medic I was trained to deal with trauma from the very basic things up to the most drastic ones you could think of, like gunshots and traumatic amputations. After  years, I left in  to join the Army, then in  I moved to the NHS. During the pandemic I was initially asked to oversee the distribution of PPE. There were shortages across the board, and having worked overseas with the Royal Marines, my logistics knowledge came to the fore. I could make sure community midwives and health visitors had what they needed. In some cases this entailed doing the deliveries myself in the van!  For me, the pleasure in the role was being able to provide medical staff with the assurance that they would have the equipment they needed. I felt I was making a real dference. When the time came to get my Covid- jab, it was one of my former soldiers who gave me it. That was very impressive because when I met him he was , wide-eyed and fresh out of the box. When I next met him he was teaching the volunteers and St John’s Ambulance staff how to administer the vaccine. I was full of admiration for him. He’d stepped up as a young man and was teaching much more mature iniduals. But I wasn’t surprised – that’s what we expected our troops to do: step into the breach, wherever the breach happens to be. You can’t praise the veterans highly enough for getting involved in the vaccine campaign. They will serve their community in whatever circumstances, whether it’s dficult or easy. You’ve got a group of people who drop everything as soon as they’re asked, regardless of what their family commitment might be, and go and do the job. I don’t think there is a better resource for the country to draw upon.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON British ArmyRoyal Air ForceNHSRoyal MarinesFalklands WarNigel JonesJake WadeHelen RobertsHospitalsSoldiersArmed forcesTeenagersThe FalklandsMost ReadRecommended

title: giant red king crabs russia
story: Giant red king crabs from Russia which can grow up to ft appear in British watersThe super-sized sea creatures have been showing up off the Yorkshire coast, where they’ve prompted feelings of both fear and joy among fishermen" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _PAY-Claws-of-a-giant-crab-a-threat-a-danger-a-caution.jpg" width"" "" There are fears the monsters might chomp up all of the scallops and brown crabs in UK watersImage: Alamy Stock PhotoByAlice Peacock:,  Jan |comments Britain is being invaded by giant red king crabs from Russia, which can grow close to ft across and weigh up to lbs. The super-sized sea creatures have been showing up off the Yorkshire coast, where they’ve prompted feelings of both fear and joy among fishermen.The iety of crab has a hard upper shell and can measure a huge  inches across the body. While the sweet-fleshed species’ popularity with chefs means they are a lucrative catch for fishermen, there are also fears the monsters might chomp up all of the scallops and brown crabs.One fisherman told theSun Online: “I’m really excited, but worried about our native seafood.” Giant red king crabs are native to North America, though scientists introduced them to Russia in the s and they thrived in the Arctic Ocean. They soon exploded in numbers, with fishermen benefiting financially from their adundance. The huge crabs then travelled to ­Norway, where they sparked another fishing boom. Most recently, the crabs have been found in UK waters where, aside from the odd one fished up in recent years, they have never been seen in signicant numbers. Fish supplier Shaun Henderson, who sells to more than  restaurants, said one of his fishermen pulled up st of king crabs off Bridlington, East Yorks this week.  It was the first time anyone in his family had caught a king crab, he said, despite them having fished in the area for two generations. While he was excited about the new catch, he was also wary, he said, due to how invasive the species seemed. The giant crabs appeared to be eating both the scallops and the brown crabs, which made Mr Henderson worry about seafood native to the UK. He said king crabs had made fishermen a lot of money in Norway, but had simultaneously depleted the populations of other sea creatures. While Will Murray, head chef at Fallow restaurant in St James’s Market, central London, has bought some of the crabs, he said he has “mixed feelings” about their appearance in the UK. While he described the giant crabs as a premium ingredient that accounted for some of the best seafood in the world, he noted there were possibly negative implications of their appearance. “We’re excited, but a bit terried, as they are invaders and could kill our brown crabs,” he said. He said the species could be the next grey squirrel, but at least they were easy to cook and enjoyable to eat. news uk-news kate-middletons-clever-trick-help-"William and Kate arrive at the Royal Variety PerformanceByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan |commentsLong before embarking on a romantic relationship, the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge were firm friends as they studied together at university. The pair both went to St Andrews University in Scotland and threw themselves into student le. This meant visiting the townaposs famous student haunts, where Kate reportedly often saw Prince William getting hit on by girls while they were out partying together. Although they werenapost an item at the time, Kate was close to the prince - and even came up with a clever trick to help him out when things got a bit awkward with members of the opposite sex.  Speaking to royal expert Katie Nicholl for her book Kate: The Future Queen, their friend Laura Warshauer said: Will was getting really hit on by this girl at a party and it was getting quite uncomfortable because he couldnapost shake her off. He was being really polite, but this girl just didnapost get the hint. All of a sudden Kate came up behind him and put her arms around him.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up. He said aposOh, sorry, but Iaposve got a girlfriendapos, and he and Kate went off giggling. William was very grateful for her help, and according to Laura, he mouthed thanks so much to her afterwards. She said: Kate was the only girl in the room who could have done that. And that was just a month after we started university. However, Kate and William didnapost stay friends for very long - thataposs because their close bond eventually blossomed into romance.  The pair began dating - staying together throughout their university days and after their graduation. In , Kate and William briefly split and sources later said the Queen was disappointed by the break-up. But the split seemed to be short-lived as weeks later, William and Kate were seen kissing at an army party at barracks in Bovington, Dorset. And in July , Kate and her brother James were seen at the Concert for Diana, held at Wembley to mark  years since William’s mother Princess Dianaaposs death. It wasn’t long before their romance was confirmed to be back on, and Kate moved into William’s Clarence House flat, where he wouldfrom military duties on Friday nights for cosy weekends together - and the rest they say is history. Theyaposve now been married almost  years and have three children - Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis. news uk-news least-popular-baby-names-uk-"What will the biggest baby names of  be ByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments Over the last few years, several names have proved the most popular with parents, including Olivia and Amelia, Muhammad and Noah.As these monikers have risen in popularity, naturally some have gone the other way - and some have even disappeared from the lists altogether.Language learning  Babbel has analysed a century of baby-name records from the Office for National Statistics and cross-referenced with newly-released  data in order to identy names that were once common - appearing in the lists of  most popular for newborns between  and  - but are now considered extinct .Theyaposve also shared a look at some of the names that are aposendangeredapos with  or fewer children receiving the name in .  Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here.According to their research, the names which have become extinct since , are Graeme, Horace, Iain, Leigh, Melvyn, Nigel and Royston for boys. And for girls, the list includes Bertha, Beverley, Carol, Carole, Doreen, Gail, Gertrude, Gillian, Glenys, Glynis, Hilary, Jeanette, Jill, Kay, Kerry, Lesley, Lindsay, Lyndsey, Lynne, Lynsey, Mandy, Maureen, Muriel, Phyllis. There were many more monikers Babbel considered to be aposendangeredapos, which were those featured in the top  between - but  or fewer babies with the name recorded in .  The at-risk names for girls were Annette, Beryl, Brenda, Carolyn, Cheryl, Dawn, Debbie, Debra, Denise, Diane, Donna, Doris, Edna, Freda, Geraldine, Gladys, Gwendoline, Hilda, Janet, Janice, Jean, Jordan, Kirsty, Lindsey, Lorraine, Lynda, Lynn, Marian, Marion, Marjorie, Marlene, Maud, Mildred, Norma, Pamela, Pauline, Sheila, Shirley, Suzanne, Thelma, Tracey, Tracy, Toni and Yvonne. Meanwhile, for boys, there were hardly any in  named Barry, Cecil, Clarence, Claude, Clford, Cyril, Dale, Donald, Gary, Garry, Glen, Glenn, Gordon, Graham, Howard, Keith, Leslie, Neville, Norman, Rodney, Stewart, Stuart and Trevor. Speaking about the findings, Ted Mentele, Editor in Didactics at Babbel, said: Naming practices form the basis of all language as well as the basis of identity. The fact that the etymological roots of these names can be traced back to dferent languages and cultures from around the world shows how languages have impacted on each other over time. We hope that by drawing attention to the overlooked roots and intriguing meanings of these endangered names, we can give them a new lease of le for the next generation, and save them from being forgotten.” While Dr Harry Parkin, Editor of The Concise Oxford Dictionary of Family Names in Britain, added: “Exactly why certain names become especially frequent and why certain names die out is very complex. Sometimes, certain vocabulary will be used because it is seen as prestigious.Popular culture is certainly a relevant aspect. Or, certain vocabulary might be used in certain groups and communities. Vocabulary useis therefore linked with a sense of identity. The Norman Conquest then had aconsiderable impact on the given name stock of England. Did your name make the endangered list  Let us know in the comments below.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Office for National StatisticsParentingBabies" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: man tattoo lipstick kiss removed
story: Man forced to get tattoo of lipstick kiss removed from bottom after we complainsThe man visited Metamorph Haus LTD, a beauty salon in Liverpool city centre, to get the inking in the intimate area removed because his partner did not like itCurtis Johnson White, owner of the beauty salon Metamorph Haus LTD has had three of his tattoos removed Image: Liverpool EchoByAaliyah RuggBradley JollyNews Wire:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments A man had a tattoo of a lipstick kiss removed from his bottom because his we disliked it as it wasnapost hers.The husband went to Metamorph Haus LTD, a beauty salon in Liverpool city centre, for the procedure after his partneraposs complaints. He was warned of the dangers of tattoo removal though, including the risk of scarring. Chris Johnson White, managing director of the beauty salon, said: Someone once came to us with a lipstick kiss on their bum and needed it removed because his we didnapost like it because it wasnapost hers.Weaposve had people come to us who have wanted a portrait of their nan for example and ended up with Boris Johnson. We get a lot of people wanting their ex partneraposs name removed. Iaposve also seen some really ugly tattoos in some really strange places and a fair few spelling mistakes. People coming to get football badges removed as well. Liverpool Echo reports young people often get large and creative inkings, the type of which Chris says he most frequently has to remove.But Chris himself came to resent his three designs - a swallow, a tribal sign and a Chinese symbol - and has had at least one removed. He also had the names of two ex-partners removed. I got them done when I was young and stupid. I just wanted tattoos but as I got older I realised they just didnapost look right, the entrepreneur added. They were dotted all over my arm and my plan was to get them removed and then possibly covered up, but now I just want them fully gone.  Iaposm over tattoos and wish Iaposd never got them in the first place. I thinktheyaposd matched Iaposd have kept them but they were random and it just looked like they had been scribbled on. Iaposd recommend people really think about their tattoo designs andthey do want one, think about the future. They are going to be there forever and they can be costly, but removals are also pricey, especiallythe tattoo is large. Tattoo removal is a slow process which takes one visit every six weeks to allow the body to heal thoroughly. Using a special machine with intense laser beams, it heats up the tattoo molecules and breaks them down so the body absorbs it and is eventually flushed out. But the darker the skin tone, or more colours used, the harder a tattoo is to remove.  Chris, who runs the beauty salon with partner Curtis Meldrum, continued: Eyebrows are also a popular one. Previously when semi-permanent make-up became a thing, eyebrows were very blocky and looked like they had been tattooed on. Whereas now, people want more of a natural look, sosomeone does have a blocky eyebrow we need to fade that as much as possible to get it removed to then be able to re-tattoo over it. That is something we see a lot of. I find women have a higher pain threshold than men but I tend to use a cooling gel or numbing cream for the process. If you do want a tattoo, think long and hard about it first. Make sure you go to a professional using high quality inks and research your artist thoroughly. If you need it removed, research the removal thoroughly. Iaposve had to revise someoneaposs removal work because theyaposd bought vouchers off the internet and it ended really bad, again it comes back to researching. And donapost get a partneraposs name tattooed on you. Partners arenapost forever but tattoos are. title: mystery remains over baby boys
story: Mystery remains over baby boys body found on golf course one year onAn inquest hearing found that despite extensive examinations by two pathologists the medical cause of the baby boys death or identity could not be ascertainedA dog walker discovered the babys body at Brackenwood Golf Course in Wirral, Merseyside Image: LIVERPOOL ECHOByAbigail NicholsonGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |commentsMystery remains following the discovery of a babyaposs body on a golf course one year ago. The remains of the boy found were found last year but the anniversary has prompted a fresh appeal by police. A dog walker discovered the babyaposs body at Brackenwood Golf Course in Wirral, Merseyside, sparking an emotional response from the community. But forensic experts were unable to establish how long the baby’s body had been at the location. A plea for the babyaposs family to come forward and DNA investigations were unsuccessful. During an inquest hearing held at Gerald Majella Courthouse in September , senior coroner Andre Rebello said despite extensive examinations by two pathologists the medical cause of death could not be ascertained.  The inquest, which lasted less than  minutes, heard it was believed the babyaposs body may have been left at the golf course at some time between December and January  or , when a groundskeeper at the course recalled seeing a bag on the ground. The Liverpool Echo reports the babyaposs remains were released for a funeral.Coroner Rebello said: The baby was buried rather than cremated in a case a relative comes forward in the future.  The funeral was held as a private service in May at Landican cemetery, Wirral. He said it was unknown whether the baby was born alive or stillborn. Detective Inspector Lynsay Armbruster said: “It has now been  months since the sad discovery of the baby’s body in Wirral. He has since been laid to rest but we would still urge his mother to come forward and speak to us.  “I hope that because some time has now passed she feels in a position to make herself known. We are not looking to attribute blame to anybody, we are simply trying to establish what happened and ensure that the mother has continued access to any vital health and social care support she may need. “I am sure that there are still people out there who know something but feel too scared or worried to come forward. I want them to feel reassured that the matter will be dealt with sensitively and all necessary help and support made available to those that need it.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON FuneralsInquests" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. figures show a district in Northern Ireland has the biggest week-on-week rise in cases in the UK.More than half of local areas around the country have seen a week-on-week rise in Covid cases as Plan B restrictions come to an end. Of the  local areas in the UK,  - % - have seen a week-on-week rise in rates. The biggest was seen in Lisburn  Castlereagh, where cases went up from ,. to ,.. This was followed by Armagh City, Banbridge  Craigavon where cases increased from ,. to ,.. The top five areas with the biggest week-on-week rises are below.  Newry, Mourne  Down in Northern Ireland continues to have the highest rate in the UK, with , new cases in the seven days to January . This is the equivalent of ,. per , people, and up from a rate of ,. for the seven days to January . Peterborough in Cambridgeshire has the third highest rate, up from ,. to ,., with , new cases. title: pervert filmed up womans skirt
story: Pervert filmed up womans skirt as she queued in Primark leaving her traumatisedThe shocked -year-old was alerted to the "degrading and embarrassing" violation of her privacy by other shoppers and she says she has been left suffering "emotional trauma" sinceKevin Syder, , from Hull, admitted recording images under the womans clothes on March ,  Image: Hull liveByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Jan A brazen upskirting pervert secretly filmed under an unsuspecting womanaposs skirt in Primark during crude, ugly, perverse, disgusting opportunist behaviour. The shocked -year-old was alerted to the degrading and embarrassing violation of her privacy and has since been left suffering emotional trauma. The disgraceful and disrespectful filming had left long-lasting effects on her and it was one of the worst days of her le, Hull Crown Court heard. Kevin Syder, , from Hull, admitted recording images under the womanaposs clothes on March , . Richard Butters, prosecuting, said that Syder was detained by security staff at Primark in Princes Quay, Hull, after being alerted by a member of the public. The witness spotted him using a phone to take photographs up the skirt of a woman standing in front of him in the queue. The shopper told the woman: Excuse me, I have just seen this man taking a photograph up your skirt.  The woman was with her younger sister at the time. There were six videos showing the womanaposs bottom and underwear that had been filmed by Syder. He attempted to run out of the store but he was fortunately detained very quickly by security staff, said Mr Butters. He was arrested and his phone was seized. It has had a very long lasting, profound impact on his victim. The woman later said: I felt myself freeze. I felt shocked. It was extremely upsetting and shocking and I was crying. I donapost even recall what I was saying. I was so shocked about what had happened. I canapost remember exactly what I was shouting. I should be able to wear whatever I wish to and not have anybody taking a photographic image up my skirt. She told the court she felt violated that her shopping had been spoiled by this happening. I feel really numb and upset, she said. The woman said that she would have to carry the incident around with her and she would be on edge the next time she went into town, especially to Primark.  This crime has left long-lasting effects on myself and my family. I think about what happened to me every day, she said. Itaposs not just the physical act of what happened but the emotional trauma from a day that stays with you. I went through one of the worst things to happen. Itaposs degrading and embarrassing. I find myself reminded of what happened. I threw away any skirt or dress that came even slightly above the knee because I genuinely felt I didnapost have the confidence to wear them. I could barely concentrate on the work I had to do. That day was one of the worst days of my le. Julia Baggs, mitigating, said Syder wanted to apologise to the victim. This was clearly an impulsive and opportunist act, said Miss Baggs. This behaviour was completely irrational. He didnapost stop and think about the impact on the complainant. He does understand the seriousness of the offence and the damage that he has caused. He is deeply remorseful and sorry for his actions. He does feel deep shame and regret and this disgraceful and disrespectful act, to use his words. He is deeply sorry for this degrading and disgraceful piece of behaviour. Syder had no previous convictions and had worked as a plasterer before becoming a long-distance lorry driver for  years before losing that job because of this offence. He had served in the Territorial Army for more than  years, the court heard. He had been married but has no children. Judge Michael Fanning told Syder: Itaposs upskirting. Itaposs a crude, ugly word and it describes crude, ugly, perverse, disgusting conduct. I am well aware that the impact on victims is very, very real. He told him the woman was entitled to wear her own choice of clothes and to expect that some pervert is not going to stick a camera under her skirt for his own sexual gratication. She should not have to feel degraded, humiliated and violated, said Judge Fanning. This was very much targeted offending. You saw an opportunity. You saw and seized that opportunity. You recorded that victim under her clothing and that was for your sexual gratication. The real risk was that you shared it. Fortunately, you were caught on the day, the video was seized and that brings it to an end. Syder was given an -week suspended prison sentence, with rehabilitation work, and he was ordered to pay £ compensation to the woman. He must register as a sex offender for seven years and the phone will be forfeited and destroyed.Follow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Primark Inc.Court caseCrown court" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news prince-charles-dreading-becoming-king-"Prince Charles meets Auschwitz survivor on Holocaust memorial dayBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments Anxious Prince Charles is aposdreadingapos the moment he takes the Crown, a top royal biographer believes.Despite training for years for the role, the emotional impact of losing his beloved mother would make the process incredibly demanding, experts fear.The Queen is preparing in the months ahead to celebrate her Platinum Jubilee as the world marks her  years on the throne.The -year-old monarchaposs passing would taken a great toll on Charles for a long time, author Penny Junor claims.She says the Prince of Wales is a very “emotional and sensitive” man who struggled with the death of his father, Prince Philip, last year. Although the -year-old has been preparing for the “top job” for a long time, he will be “devastated” to take the throne from his mother, she says. The biographer told Podcast Royal: “This is a moment that he has been dreading all his le. By achieving the top job, the job he’s been training for and preparing for all these years does inevitably means the death of his mother and he loves his mother very dearly. “So it’s going to be a very vicious week, moment and I think that I am sure that he is pretty terried of the whole prospect.  He is a very emotional man and a sensitive man, he did take the death of his father very badly. He takes the death of any loved one to heart and I think it would be, it’s devastating for him as it is for anyone who loses a much-loved mother.”Last year, a poll found the public want the Crown to bypass Charles and go to Prince William when the Queen’s reign ends.Deltapoll interviewed , adults and found a generational ide over who should take the throne - with younger people even calling for rebel prince Harry to become king.  It was a blow to Prince Charles, after great strides to improve his public image over the past two decades. Royal commentator Jonathan Sacerdoti believes Charles will become the successor - but feels certain things will change. Charles is set to be a very dferent monarch to the Queen, he reckons. I certainly know that the monarchy will want to keep itself modern and agile in relation to the UK and the Commonwealth and keep itself relevant, Sacerdoti stated. Plenty of them absolutely love the Queen and the monarchy and that handover have already started with Prince Charles. I would imagine on their agenda is to keep their Commonwealth but it is inevitable over time that peopleaposs attitudes towards royalty and the monarchy might change and sht. I think thataposs why theyaposve been very careful to try to adapt and change with the times and Charles has also shown some indication that he might be quite the dferent monarch from his mother. title: ridiculous food prices costing hard
story: Ridiculous food prices are costing hard-working people an arm and a legIn this weeks column Val, the mum of Mirror columnist and football legend Robbie Savage, gets her knickers in a twist at the price of a roast dinner, and wants to bobsleigh at the Beijing Winter OlympicsFood prices are on the rise Image: Bloomberg via Getty ImagesopinionByVal Savage:,  Jan |comments A man called Clive paid £ for a leg of lamb from Tesco and his we’s rage went viral, as the cool young people say on Instagram. She was so incensed she had to later send out a message confirming ‘Clive is alive’.I’m not surprised she was furious. THIRTY POUNDS  I’d want a whole sheep and a field of turnips for that. Now I love a roast dinner more than most. Just thinking about tender meat soaking up gravy makes me drool. But come on, prices are getting ridiculous.I was going to wax lyrical about how mutton can taste just as delicious, and how scrag ends of meat in a stew contains the same goodness. I was tempted to suggest putting lesser cuts of meat in a big pie to make a substantial meal for half the price.  But then I stopped myself and thought: why, decades after our parents had rations, are we having to think this way  Why are we putting up with outrageous price rises on essentials  Why are honest, hardworking people punished in the pocket and at the dinner table  My dad always said, whenever the budget announcements were made, working people were hit hardest with the increased price of a pint and packet of cigarettes. Now it’s food. Thinking about it left me angrier than Clive’s we. Bittersweet time for Her Majesty Staying at Wood Farm cottage at Sandringham in the run up to the th anniversary of her father’s death next weekend will be extra emotional for the Queen as it’s the first time she’s been there without Prince Philip. I imagine it will feel comforting one moment, heartbreaking the next. The rooms, the gardens, the views and even the smells will remind her of the good times she’s had there, but the people she shared them with are gone. Loch Lomond is the special place where Colin and I enjoyed our special times. Each year I’d askhe’d like to have a holiday in Portugal or Loch Lomond, and he always chose Scotland. We loved everything about our trips there, from the long drive with our Motown music, Scotch eggs and tin of travel sweets. We’d always stop at Tebay services which has beautul scenery, turkey pie to die for and a farm shop.  We stayed in a cosy lodge, where even a cup of tea or a Chinese takeaway seemed to taste nicer. We’d walk in the wilderness for miles, spotting red deer, and we’d end up at little tea shops where it would have been rude not to order cake. Sometimes we’d drive to explore the surrounding areas and we’d get lost, in the days before sat nav, but somehow always found a warm, friendly pub. Colin loved the gentle pace and peace of our holidays there. And I adored how everything about the place made us both feel so relaxed and happy. I get a little tearful when Loch Lomond appears on television. Then I remind myself I was lucky to have had such fantastic times there.  Bloominapos solo birthday While Boris had a party for his birthday, I spent mine alone. My two sons bought me flowers and left them at the end of the drive because we wouldn’t have dreamt of breaking the social distance laws. I am too tired to be angry. Listening to all the political rows has left me weary and drained. Instead, I just wish all sides of the political spectrum would get their heads together and get our country up and running again.  Drama a real blast It can be hard to stay awake in January when it’s a long, grey, damp anticlimax. But an explosion scene in the new TV series Trigger Point made me jump out of my skin. My eyes popped so wide I felt more awake than I had in weeks.  Loo are you talking to  Fancy new research says lots of British phrases are no longer used because the younger generation are baffled by them. What a load of codswallop. Whoever did the survey needs to listen to my daily chat with my friend Beryl because we use such phrases constantly. I say this as a woman who still calls those sweets Opal Fruits and will never say Starburst. So here’s my guide to those sayings which have got young people’s knickers in a twist. Flogging a dead horse means there’s no point in arguing any more - that’s what I say whenever I’m giving our Robert a talking-to because he never he pays any notice. I’m fit for the knacker’s yard means every bit of me is falling to pieces and no use to anyone, which is how I describe myself these days.  Dropping a clanger is a less posh way of saying committing a faux pas - something my friends say I do every day. No wonder no one understands that ‘spend a penny’ means going to the loo because they usually cost a pound now. And a dog’s dinner is what I create each time I try cooking. But I have no idea where ‘daft as a brush’ comes from - or why my friends use it whenever they talk about me. Bobsleigh, the coolest sport The Australian Open tennis has turned my body clock upside down because I’m glued to the coverage. Soon I’ll be riveted by the Beijing Olympic Winter Games. The bobsleigh is my favourite. Me and my friend Janet reckonwe could get in one we’d shoot down faster than anyone . But we’d laugh so hysterically there’d need to be room in my skin-tight race suit for a Tena Lady.If you’d like to write to Val, please email features@mirror or write to Val Savage, PO Box , E DD The Mirror makes a donation to the Alzheimer’s Society in lieu of payment. alzheimersRead MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Novak DjokovicPrince Philip, Duke of EdinburghRobbie SavageAustralian OpenWinter Olympic GamesRoyal FamilyMental healthPrice risesAlzheimers diseaseBobsledDaily Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: school bans year 11 pupils
story: School bans Year  pupils from loo breaks during lessons in zero-tolerance approachUlidia Integrated College in Co Antrim, Northern Ireland, has defended its strict toilet policy where the loos operate as a one-in one-out policy at break and lunchtimes -pupils want to use the loo during lessons they need to have a medical card or exemptionUlidia Integrated College in Co Antrim, Northern Ireland, has defended its strict toilet policy Image: Ulidia Integrated CollegeByLauren HarteAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Jan |comments A secondary school bans Year  pupils from going to the loo during lessons over Covid- breaches and vandalism. Ulidia Integrated College in Co Antrim, Northern Ireland, has defended its strict toilet policy where the loos operate as a one-in one-out policy at break and lunchtimes.Requests to use the loo during class time will be refused unless the pupil shows a medical card or exemption to the teacher, parents were informed via email.Furthermore, pupils who need to use the toilet outside the specied times during their period will need a note from their parents, which will then be dated and counter-signed by their form teacher, BelfastLive reports.  The school said it has been dealing with ious issues amongst an increasing number of Year  pupils, which included disrespecting staff, misuse of toilets, unorm breaches, Covid- breaches, and vandalism. The school has said that from January  it was implementing a zero-tolerance approach.One parent Ciaran McCauley told BBC Radio Ulsteraposs Evening Extra on Thursday: My son is in Year  at the school and he came home on Friday last and was quite concerned because he had become aware of the email that had gone out to the parents of Year  students.It doesnapost affect my son directly but he was able to empathise with the issues that might be impacting the other students.  He complained that the toilets were being locked and students and parents had been asked to supply notes. If the children needed to access toiletsthey were on their period, they had to bring a note in, have it counter-signed by a teacher and dated. Ciaran believes itaposs an unfair policy and wrong. He added: I thought it was regressive and led to embarrassing situations for kids. Unfortunately, we live in a society where periods still have a stigma attached to them and theyaposre still an embarrassment for many.  Ciaran initially thought the email was a rumour, but when he contacted the school they confirmed it. In a statement, principal Michael Houston said: As a rights respecting school, Ulidia Integrated College is in full support of the Period Dignity Project, which refers to the accessibility and availability of essential care needed to support a period in conjunction with the removal and breaking of stigma and taboo around periods. Education is a key factor in breaking the stigma surrounding periods and promoting respect, understanding and open discussions about what people may experience. Following repeated incidents of vandalism and breaches of Covid- safeguards in the toilets, many of which occurred during lesson times, some facilities had to be closed, replaced or repaired. We want to ensure that all pupils in the particular year group affected are always given access to clean and sanitary facilities during their period. Mr Houston added that the measures are temporary and protective, only relevant for the pupils in a single year group who have to leave during lessons as facilities are freely available before school, at break and lunch time, end of day and between lessons as required. He added: In addition all single person all access toilets are open too all pupils all day every day without exception. It comes two months after a Co Down grammar school was criticised for its toilet policy after it emerged there were just three toilets for , pupils.The rules about going to the toilet imposed at Glenlola Collegiate School in Bangor were labelled “draconian”.Thehas contacted the school for a comment. title: storm malik severe 80mph gales
story: Storm Malik: Severe mph gales, heavy rain and snow to batter the countryThe UK is set to be hit by mph winds as well as heavy rain and snow over the weekend as Storm Malik sweeps in from the North East with yellow and amber warnings in placeStorm Malik is set to bring mph gusts to the UK Image: PAByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan |commentsBrits are being warned of damaging gusts of wind up to mph that could batter the UK along with heavy rain and snow as Storm Malik sweeps in.A stormy weekend picture is predicted by the Met Office due to the severe winds and showers while it will also be cold with temperatures dropping to close to zero going into Sunday morning and snow is expected to fall in Scotland. Yellow weather warnings are in place across all of Scotland, northern England and parts of Northern Ireland for most of Saturday as Storm Malik moves in from the north east bringing the wind and rain.But there is a more severe amber warning for eastern Scotland, where damaging gusts of wind will likely cause disruption to road, rail, air and ferry services. Power supplies and mobile phone coverage could also be affected.  The Met Office warned: Injuries and danger to le could occur from flying debris as well as from large waves and beach material being thrown onto sea fronts, coastal roads and properties.And Met Office forecaster Luke Miall said of the winds:Widely  to  but we could see ,  and even mph gusts especially towards the North East so we do have an amber warning in place across north eastern Scotland, that’s damaging gusts of wind that could cause some signicant disruption.”He added:We also have this sequence of rain bringing some very wet weather as well for a time. SP Energy Networks, the company responsible for electricity transmission in central and southern Scotland, issued safety advice around potential power cuts.  The company said customers should keep a battery or wind-up torch to hand and keep mobile phones fully charged. People should also beware of fallen power lines, it said. Network Rail Scotland said it would introduce some speed restrictions for safety, and have additional staff equipped with chainsaws across the network to deal with fallen trees on tracks. Named by the Danish Meteorological Institute, Storm Malik is expected to bring in gusts reaching up to mph in coastal areas, but more widely mph, as it tracks eastwards towards Denmark.  Paul Gunderson, chief meteorologist for the Met Office, said: The impacts of Storm Malik are going to be greatest in Denmark on Sunday, but the track of the storm in the preceding hours means that the UK will be dealt a glancing blow as Malik moves eastwards on Saturday. For those in the north of the UK there will be high winds and rain on Saturday, with showers possibly turning wintry in the high ground in the north. The highest winds are expected in exposed coastal areas in the north and east of Scotland, but it will be a windy day for most. Further south, the weekend weather will feature some blustery winds and some rain.  The storm will also drive a cold front southwards, with temperatures set to come down throughout Saturday and widespread frost expected to form across the UK in the night into Sunday. More very strong winds are expected as another low pressure system moves across northern areas on Sunday, with some snow possible across parts of Scotland. It is out towards Wales, Northern Ireland and Scotland that we will see the increasingly windy weather, starting to develop, said Mr Miall. Some hill snow for Scotland, we are keeping a close eye on that. Another yellow warning for wind is in place for the northern UK from pm on Sunday until noon on Monday. UK forecast for the next  days Today: Very windy Scotland and north England with rain in northwest moving south and easing. Brighter skies with some showers following. Cloudy and mild most of England and Wales with drizzle in west. Clearer skies arriving from north during afternoon. Tonight: Winds easing overnight with good clear spells developing leading to a widespread frost. Showers in the northeast slowly dying out. Sunday: Cold, bright start for many but becoming cloudier. Rain and strong winds developing in north with very strong winds for west and south Scotland and some snow for north Scotland. Outlook for Monday to Wednesday: Very windy start to Monday, with rain clearing to showers, these wintry in the north. Milder, though often blustery for Tuesday and Wednesday. Some persistent rain for the northwest. title: stunning mansion house pool secret
story: Stunning mansion house with pool has secret Lord of the Rings-themed gardenThe stunning Grade II listed home in St. Margarets-at-Clfe, Dover, Kent is on the market for £. million and would be a favourite with Lord of the Rings fansA six-bed house has a secret that is perfect for any JRR Tolkien fan Image: Sothebys International RealtyByAndy CrickLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Jan |commentsA six-bed house has a secret that is perfect for any JRR Tolkien fan - a Lord of the Rings-themed garden. The Grade ll Listed baronial gothic manor house oozes elegance with castle turrets on the roof and its sweeping staircase in the hall. The th century property boasts a library, outdoor swimming pool, tennis courts, a gym and cellars. The bedrooms include one with a four poster bed. But itaposs not until prospective buyers walk through the picturesque walled garden that the real treat is revealed.  A Hobbit Hole - like that inhabited by Bilbo and Froddo Baggins in the fantasy books and Hollywood blockbusters - is hidden in the woodland. The tiny, green painted shed even comes with a trademark circular door. But the magic doesnapost end there, there is also a stunning tree house - complete with lighting and a fireplace.  The elf-like wooden hut is built up in the branches and access is gained via two rope bridges. The house in St. Margarets-at-Clfe, Dover, Kent is on the market for £.million with Sothebyaposs International Realty. The Rightmove listing reads: Oxney Court is an elegant Grade ll baronial gothic manor house located on the Kent coast. It has extensive grounds and formal gardens together with further accommodation in two cottages.  It is situated in a most secluded and discrete setting, accessed by a long private drive. Oxney Court has an interesting history. Whilst there has been a house on this site for a few hundred years the current house dates from the late th century.  Substantial gates open to a driveway which passes through ancient woodland before continuing through more formal gardens on approaching the house. A striking entrance porch leads to an octagonal reception hall with stone flooring.  Moving through, the staircase hall has a stone fireplace and a sweeping staircase leading to the first floor landing. Beyond, the elegant principal reception rooms stretch across the front of the house. The main accommodation is provided over three floors. The ground floor accommodation consists of a fine, generously proportioned dining room which is in the gothic style. There is a large bow window with detailing and a high ceiling with ornate mouldings. The drawing room has a striking mirrored wall and a double sided fireplace to the end of the room which also opens into the library with fitted bookshelves.  Beyond is the triple aspect sitting room which, like the dining room, has gothic detail. Together these rooms provide a wonderful space for both family living and formal entertaining. A spacious corridor leads to a double aspect study, led with oak and on to the kitchen breakfast room. The kitchen is fitted with handmade oak units arranged around an island unit and is naturally illuminated by a large roof light.  An elegant hexagonal conservatory is set to the southern corner of the house and views of the garden to the rear. The first floor consists of elegant and spacious bedroom suites. The master bedroom is of good proportions having a bow window with easterly views and double doors to a well appointed bathroom. This can also be approached from the tower staircase. From here, double doors overlook the turreted porch below. The family bathroom is situated to the rear of the first floor. Across the front of the house are three well-appointed suites, the largest enjoying a triple aspect. A fth bedroom is found at the rear, adjacent to which is a large rooftop balcony with a southerly aspect.  There are cellars and store rooms beneath the main house. But then the Lord of the Rings surprise is revealed as it adds: The gardens and grounds are laid to areas of lawn interspersed with laurels and rhododendrons and surrounded by deep belts of trees and woodland.The lawns are underplanted with a great iety of flowering bulbs, shrubs and other plants and the more formal garden to the rear of the house has deep herbaceous borders enclosed by yew hedging and high brick walls.There is a further area of garden, mostly laid to lawn, as well as a rose garden which is enclosed by box hedging, and an arbour. In the woods there is a magnicent tree house with rope bridges and a hobbit house. news uk-news sue-gray-plans-send-report-"Sue Gray report: Met Police request ‘minimal reference’ByAbigail OLearyNews ReporterDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |comments Sue Gray plans to send a cut-back version of her report to Downing Street “shortly” after y talks with the Met Police concluded, the Mirror understands. The report is expected to be sent to No in the coming hours or days after Ms Gray handed over evidence of possible lockdown breaches to Scotland Yard.No will then decide when to publish it, with the government previously suggesting this would happen when Parliament is sitting - which is next on Monday.  However, the report is set to follow the Met Police request to include only “minimal reference” to Downing Street parties the force is investigating. It is unclearor when a fuller report with all the details will be published, after the Met finishes its investigation. The politan Police asked the top civil servant to make minimal references to the parties it is investigating in her report to avoid prejudicing its inquiry. Scotland Yard is looking at a number of events in Downing Street and Whitehall during the pandemic - but the force has not specied which ones.Reports have suggested it could be as many as eight gatherings. At the same time, Sue Grayaposs report had been expected this week but the timing has been thrown into chaos by the Metaposs bombshell announcement of a police probe on Tuesday. The Whitehall inquiry is understood to be still ongoing but Ms Gray may be forced to decide whether to delay her report or strip out key details. Opposition MPs blasted the appearance of an establishment stitch-up and a Whitehall whitewash, which could buy Boris Johnson a reprieve.The Prime Minister will spend the weekend at his Chequers retreat as he seeks to shore up his battered leadership. In a statement on Friday, Scotland Yard said: For the events the Met is investigating, we asked for minimal reference to be made in the Cabinet Office report. The Met did not ask for any limitations on other events in the report, or for the report to be delayed, but we have had ongoing contact with the Cabinet Office, including on the content of the report, to avoid any prejudice to our investigation. However some legal figures questioned why publishing the Whitehall report would prejudice the police investigation. title: tv celebrity couple call lawyers
story: TV celebrity couple call in lawyers over alleged online sex-tape leakA famous television duo have called in lawyers to remove sex videos and images that have been shared on social media accounts via direct messages, it is allegedA television couple called in lawyers over alleged sex tapesByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan A well-known television couple called in lawyers after sex tapes were shared on social media, it is reported. The videos and pics of the pair are believed to have been put online and shared between social media accounts via direct messages. Lawyers acting for the celebrity duo are then understood to have had the material removed more than three weeks afterwards, The Sun reports. The high-profile couple would have been “mortied” with the content going online said an industry source but they moved quickly to have it removed.The person told The Sun : “They would have been mortied by the leak. “Their fans will have been horried on their behalf to think their private content was online for anyone to see. “By moving quickly and having it removed they have done the right thing.” The high-profile couple have taken part in prime time shows on British television. It is not knownthey went to the police to report the sex tapes going online. A  law in England and Wales has made it illegal to show private sexual content without the person’s approval.  It was introduced to try and tackle revenge porn and an offender could now face a maximum two year prison sentence. There have been many high-profile cases of sex tapes going into the public domain and being a source of embarrassment for celebrities. In , Pamela Anderson and Mötley Crüe drummer Tommy Lee made headlines across the globe when their previously stolen sex tape was sold by a disgruntled employee.Other celebrities who are known to have sex tapes in their past include Paris Hilton and Kim Kardashian.Parisapos tape - the so-called One Night in Paris - was leaked in , while Kim and her former boyfriend Ray Japoss tape leaked in . Earlier this week, Ray J called for an end to speculation he and Kim had starred in another sex tape, after the billionaire reality TV star denied its existence. news uk-news uk-weather-exact-times-storm-"Storm Malik: Met Office warns of windy conditionsByBradley JollyNews Wire:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |commentsStorm Malik is expected to batter monster winds and huge rainfall across parts of the UK today - and forecasters have warned of a loss of power and travel delays.Amber and yellow weather warnings are in place for wind until Tuesday as the weather front moves in from the northwest.Itaposll be most severe across eastern Scotland and northeast England today, with gales of up to mph feared. Met Office says road, rail, air and ferry services are likely to be affected, leading to longer journey times and some cancellations. Some roads and bridges likely to close too.There is also a good chance power cuts may occur, with the potential to affect other services, such as mobile phone coverage, forecasters say. The storm will slowly move south, asdetails, and will impact the East Midlands and East of England by Monday evening. Storm Corrie will, meanwhile, bring a new spell of rainfall and gusts across Scotland in the middle of the week.  Today The amber weather warning is in place for eastern Scotland and northeast England throughout today. Met Office said: An area of very strong west or northwest winds will cross Scotland and notheast England on Saturday morning in association with Storm Malik before easing during the afternoon. The strongest winds are expected in the east of Scotland and northeast of England later in the morning. Gusts of widely - mph are likely with a short period of gusts in excess of  mph possible, particularly for Moray and north Aberdeenshire as well as the Lothians.  The amber warning covers central Scotland, Tayside  Fe, Grampian, southwest Scotland and the Lothian Borders. North East England is also covered, including Newcastle and Northumberland. A yellow weather warning is in place for all of Scotland, much of Northern Ireland and parts of northern England today for wind too. Met Office added: An area of strong winds will cross Scotland, parts of Northern Ireland and some northern counties of England on Saturday morning before easing during the afternoon. Gusts of widely - mph are expected and there is a chance of a brief period of gusts in excess of  mph in places, particularly for parts of eastern Scotland later in the morning.  Met Officeaposs chief meteorologist Paul Gundersen said: “The impacts of Storm Malik are going to be greatest in Denmark on Sunday, but the track of the storm in the preceding hours means that the UK will be dealt a glancing blow as Malik moves eastwards on Saturday. “For those in the north of the UK there will be high winds and rain on Saturday, with showers possibly turning wintry in the high ground in the north. The highest winds are expected in exposed coastal areas in the north and east of Scotland, but it will be a windy day for most.” Sunday The yellow weather warning remains in place throughout Sunday for all of Scotland, most of northeast England, northwest England and parts of Northern Ireland and north Wales. Travel disruption is likely in these spots, and the weather will generate some large and dangerous waves around the coasts. Met Office said road, rail, air and ferry services may be affected, with longer journey times and cancellations possible.  Injuries and danger to le could occur from large waves and beach material being thrown onto susceptible sea fronts, coastal roads and properties, forecasters added. Gusts could reach up to mph in hilly and coastal areas, including along the North Sea shore. Met Office continued: On Sunday evening a spell of strong northwesterly winds is likely to develop across western Scotland, and then progress southeastwards eventually easing away from the North Sea coastlines during Monday morning. The strongest wind gusts will mostly occur around the coastlines and over the hills. Monday Sundayaposs yellow weather warning - and the areas subject to it - will remain throughout Monday too. Met Office said: Thereaposs a small chance that a very limited part of the area could see a short period of more damaging gusts, that could reach -mph inland, and -mph around exposed coasts and hills. Temperatures will remain in single figures on Monday. Agostinho Sousa, a consultant in public health medicine, has urged Britons to remind elderly neighbours to heat their homes. “Cold weather can have a serious impact on health, particularly for older people and those with heart and lung problems, as it increases the risks of heart attacks, strokes and chest infections. “Remind vulnerable relatives and neighbours to heat their home to at least C – particularlythey have reduced mobility, are  or older, or have a health condition. “Should they need to go outside, it’s important for them to wear shoes with a good grip.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Met OfficeWeatherWeather warning" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
