title: woman 37 weighing just 3
story: Exclusive: Woman, , weighing just  stone starving to death as eating causes agonyNicolette Baker, from Truro, Cornwall, has never been able to properly start her le due to the horric condition which means she cant eat without incredible pain Image: Greg Martin   Cornwall LiveByHollie BoneNews Reporter:,  Jan |commentsA woman who is literally aposstarving to deathapos with a rare condition needs a final £, before she can undergo treatment to save her le. Nicolette Baker was diagnosed with Superior Mesenteric Artery syndromenearly a decade ago - a condition which means that her Superior Mesenteric artery is compressing on her duodenum and kidney -causing her unimaginable pain when she tries to eat.A -year-old says eating something as small as a jelly baby feels like sheaposs aposfinished off a Christmas dinner apos and makes her intestine feel like itaposs aposgoing to burstapos.Over the years she had been misdiagnosed as anorexic and even force-fed, as her weight has dwindled to a terrying st. In March last year doctors told her she had aposdays to liveapos, meaning they would only offer her palliative care.  But defiant Nicolette wants to live and has already raised £, towards £, for surgery in Germany to relieve the pressure and pain her artery is causing. Nicolette said: The surgery is booked but I need to pay for the weeks Iaposll be spending in intensive care afterwards because my health is so poor. There’s only two weeks to go I’m really determined to keep going. I used to thinkI’m going to die I’m going to die but things have changed. Now I’ve actually been told I’m dying I don’t just want to surrender to that, I want to live and give something back to society.After being given days to live Nicolette became determined to defy doctorsapos predictions and earlier this month set up a GoFundMe where she opened up about how she is aposliterally starving to deathapos. Although Nicolette only received her diagnosis seven years ago, doctors believe she was born with the condition. Nicolette can recall having issues with her digestive system from as young as four years old, but it wasnapost until her late s that she would understand what was happening to her. She said: Eating a jelly baby feels like I’ve finished off a full Christmas dinner. As that jelly baby passes through my intestine the pain is incredible. It feels like a hose pipe with a blockage in it to the point where it is going to burst. She added: I remember throwing up liquid milk at four years old. I was just labelled as anorexic but when I eat it causes me so much pain.  The less I ate the less pain I’d have so I ended up losing quite a bit of weight and it was deemed to be a mental health problem.I was an inpatient at hospitals for years and I was force fed which only made the problem worse and caused me even more pain.The condition has completely robbed Nicolette of her le - she has been unable to start a family, have a career and was even forced to give up her beloved -year-old whippet, Eden. She said: I have always dreamed of my prince charming coming on a white horse but I don’t think that will happen. I had to give up my beloved dog because I couldn’t manage him anymore. The first thing I will do when Iaposve had the surgery is get him back. Before her health declined, Nicolette had worked part time in a hospice, until she could no longer even manage that - meaning she has no savings of her own to fall back on.  Now, as the condition holds her on the brink of death, it is a race against time to raise the final £, needed so she has secured her follow up treatment after her surgery on February . She said It would mean everything to raise the last £, I need so I donapost have that pressure hanging over me. Iaposm struggling with my breathing, my whole system is shutting down one by one. Iaposm desperate to make it through just so I can thank all the people who have so generously helped me get to this point. Nicolette will fly out on February  for preliminary scans ahead of the surgery at the end of the month. title: nasa reveals new plan detect
story: NASA reveals new plan to detect possible ‘doomsday asteroids’ near EarthNasa has upgraded its asteroid hazard software to the new Sentry-II algorithm hoping to get more accurate results for known hazards and find new onesNasa has new software to make its potentially hazardous asteroid detection better Image: Getty ImagesByLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |commentsNasa has made improvements to its asteroid hazard software so it should now be able to detect dangerous space rocks with better accuracy. Thereaposs no aposdoomsday asteroidapos hurtling towards us imminently that we know of but astronomers check regularly just in case. Nasaaposs Jet Propulsion Laboratoryuses a special software to analysepossibly hazardous asteroids could hit Earth. And now the agency is upgrading the software for the first time in  years with a new Sentry-II algorithm. It works by frequently scanning a list of asteroids and their orbits that are already known to be possibly hazardous and then calculatesany known or new asteroids could potentially hit Earth.  The system being used is known as the Yarkovsky effect, referring to how an asteroid absorbs sunlight and emits it as heat.This heat impacts the asteroidaposs path and can be the possibility of it hitting Earth, , reports the Sun.Sentry, the original software, was previously unable to do this.  Scientists had to previously do manual calculations to work out the Yarkovsky effect so the software upgrade will make a massive dference. Nasa keeps an eye on almost , near-Earth asteroids currently, and itaposs hoped the software upgrade will help them see more. Thousands of new asteroids can be discovered each year. And in , the agency is aiming to launch its Near Earth ObjectSurveyor mission so it will have a spacecraft focused solely on hunting for asteroids. Itaposs expected the spacecraft could find  per cent of asteroids  feet or bigger inin the first  years after launching. title: parents whose two children niece
story: Parents whose two children and niece drowned after they drove into floodwater avoid jailDaniel and Lacey Rawlings were given  months of supervised probation without jail time in their sentencing on Thursday,Daniel and Lacey RawlingsByMirror:,  Jan |commentsA couple whose two children and niece drowned when the family car drove into a flooded creek in  have escaped jail time. Daniel and Lacey Rawlings were given  months of supervised probation without jail time in their sentencing on Thursday. In a Colorado court, Judge Timothy Wright sentenced Daniel to  months of probation and , hours of community service, while Lacey received  months of supervised probation and  hours of community service.The horror incident happened on November  of , after a period of heavy rain in the area north of Phoenix,People reported.The Bar X Crossing at Tonto Creek had flooded and authorities had placed a barricade to turn vehicles away from the area. Daniel was driving the military-style vehicle, with seven children in the back.  Authorities alleged that he drove the vehicle around the barricade and through the creek - a journey he had made several times earlier that day. However, this time the vehicle was swept up in the rushing water. The parents and four of the children were rescued by helicopter, but the three other children did not survive. The bodies of the coupleaposs -year-old son, Colby, and the boyaposs cousin, -year-old Austin, were recovered the following morning, while the body of Colby’s sister, -year-old Willa, was found two weeks later on the edge of the lake, several miles away. Both Daniel and Lacey were each initially charged with seven counts of child abuse.  Daniel, who was behind the wheel of the vehicle, was also charged with three counts of involuntary manslaughter. In December, Daniel entered a guilty plea to three counts of manslaughter and seven counts of child abuse. Meanwhile, Lacey pleaded guilty to one count of child abuse. Speaking in court on Thursday afternoon, Lacey described the incident as a “mistake [she agonizes] over every minute”.  “I will continue to agonize over it for the rest of my le, she said. Iaposm so sorry. Lacey went on to describe her surviving children as being her “world”. My kids are the reason I get out of bed every single day. My kids are the reason I found a way to move on. They deserve a happy le. They deserve a mother who tries her absolute hardest to give them everything they need. Daniel took the stand next to read a prepared statement.  I wish every day that I could go back and relive and redo the events of that horric day, he said. I wish I could take that trauma and carry it myself. I wish I could take everybodyaposs pain and bottle it up and hold it myself because nobody deserves to endure pain that I have caused them. While many family members spoke on the couple’s behalf, at least one relative urged the judge not to be too lenient. Austin’s grandmother, Lynn Morey, told the judge she still has nightmares about the incident. Cutting corners when it comes to childrenaposs safety is a deal-breaker,” she said. Thanksgiving has never been the same since. That feeling of dread lingers throughout the weekend, overshadowing everything our family does, despite our attempts to live through this, be grateful and move on. The coupleaposs probation begins immediately. news weird-news car-button-de-ices-windscreen-"Driving tip: How to defrost your windscreenByZahna EklundAudience writerLuke Chillingsworth:,  Jan |commentsWe all know how unforgiving the icy winter months can be, and for those of us that drive, scraping the ice off of your car windscreen in the early hours of the morning can be a real chore. But thanks to a tip from a driving school TikTok account named Driving Test Success @drivingtestsuccess, we no longer need to suffer in the freezing cold before we head to work, as it turns out you can actually get rid of the ice from inside your car as itaposs warming up. Experts at Driving Test Success say you can clear ice cover by simply activating your car windscreen fan, which will heat up the glass from the inside and help to melt the frost, the Express reports. In the companyaposs video, they explained: “Frozen windscreen  Put the temperature on high.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. “Put the front windscreen fan on max. The ice will start to melt from the heat. Wipe away excess water andthe fan to normal. While the tip might seem obvious to some seasoned drivers, several commenters on the video who were new to driving couldnapost believe theyaposd never seen the hack before. One commenter said: Wow, magic! The ice is gone. And another praised the account for all their help, as they wrote: Iaposve learnt so much thanks to your app!  But others were less impressed, as one TikTok user shunned the idea, stating: Wastes more fuel. Just get [out] and scrape it off you lazy so and so.” Driving Test Success is far from the first account to point out the easy de-icing trick either, as another video online from Clear View Driving said road users should use their demister before they start driving. They said: “Now donapost use your windscreen wipers or washers as that wonapost help. Turn on your front and rear demister. “The rear demister also heats up your side mirrors in most new cars. Butthe mirrors are not clear, make sure to clear them before you start driving. “Then, once itaposs done you can use your wipers.” And in the cold winter months, the AA has also encouraged road users to “turn on the warm air blower” and “heated mirrors” to clear frost cover quickly and safely.They explained: “Start the engine and turn on the warm air blower on the windscreen. Switch on the rear windscreen heater and heated mirrors,you have them. Turn on the air-con. Itaposs not just for summer – itaposll remove moisture from the air to stop the car from misting up. “Don’t use your hands to wipe misted-up windows – youaposll leave greasy smears and a diamond ring could scratch the glass. Use a lint-free absorbent clothnecessary. “Stay with your car the whole time while the engineaposs running.” What do you think is the best way to de-ice your car  Let us know in the comments below. news weird-news cleaning-fanatics-obsessed-p-washing-"TikTok user shares dish soap hackByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Jan |comments Sometimes it feels like you can only wear a white piece of clothing once, before it gets stained and its colour dulls after just one spin in the washing machine. No matter how hard you try, those whites always end up looking grey. However, one TikTok trend doing the rounds on social media promises to have your whites looking bright, and the best bit is, itaposll only set you back a few pence. The hack was shared by one user, @burcibaci, who revealed the one simple and cheap item you need to add to your wash to ensure those whites stay white - washing up liquid.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. All you need to do is add a small amount of washing up liquid to a small cap, before throwing it in the washer with your white load, although the TikToker recommends you do this in addition to your washing detergent, rather than in its place. aposaposI would also add your detergent too for the best clean, she wrote alongside the clip, which has since been viewed more than , times. Although she used a pale coloured Fairy Liquid, other TikTok users recommended blue soaps as they can be used to cancel out the yellow tones in the white materials. Many people questioned how the bubbles from the soap didnapost overflow, but @burcibaci simply explained that you only have to use a very small amount for it to be effective. It also makes a great stain remover! One part dawn dish soap, one part hydrogen peroxide, one helpful TikToker commented. Everyday is a school day.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: four bedroom home goes sale
story: Four-bedroom home goes on sale for £.m - and it comes with its own tourist attractionA unique four-bedroom house has hit the market for a whopping £. million - and the lucky buyer will also bag a huge cave that tourists flock to visit every yearThe house seems unassuming from the outside Image: Jam Press Ryan NewberryByZahna EklundAudience writerRia Newman:,  Jan |commentsMost of us have a pretty good idea of what our dream home would look like, andyour idea of property perfection includes living next to - and owning - a tourist hotspot, you might just be in luck. A four-bedroom property in the city of Versailles in Missouri, USA, has just gone on the market for . million , and while the house may look unassuming from the outside, itaposs the additional land you get alongside the home that makes the purchase worth it. The house comes with a whopping  acres of land - and a historic cave that serves as a tourist attraction.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Named Jacobaposs Cave, the underground chasm was discovered by Jacob Craycraft in  and quickly became a popular haunt for tourists visiting the area.The location has been operational with a regular cave show since  and has stunning rock formations inside - including sea coral, and massive stalactites and columns. According to estate agents, the lucky buyer of the four-bedroom, four-bathroom house will be able to generate a generous annual income from visitors to Jacobaposs Cave - meaning you could happily live and work from your own home. The  acres surrounding the home includes a car park for visitors, while the remaining land could be used as a campsite to bring in even more revenue - although the current occupiers host three large gatherings for traders a year on the extra space. The listing reads: “With an available staff possessing knowledge of the business, you will be able to hit the ground runningyou should choose to continue maintaining this unique business and tourist attraction. “This opportunity is truly once-in-a-letime and has so much more potential you will have to see to fully appreciate.” And itaposs not all about the tourist attraction, as the house itself is a large two-storey property with plenty of space to raise a family or to relax after a long dayaposs work. Whataposs more, the home is nearby the famous Lakes of the Ozarks reservoir - which is a popular lake destination for both tourists and local residents, with more than , miles of shoreline to enjoy. The property is currently on the market with Justin Swast at Midwest Land Group. What do you think of the unique property  Let us know in the comments below. title: mortgage expert bewildered woman blows
story: Mortgage expert bewildered as woman blows £, deposit money on psychic readingA mortgage expert has recalled the most bizarre issue shes ever had with a client, when a woman sent over her bank statements ahead of the sale going through - but all her money was goneJordans video went viral Image: @anutterhomeloan TIKTOKByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Jan |comments A home loan advisor has gone viral online after sharing the aposcraziestapos thing sheaposs ever seen on a clientaposs bank statements. In a clip posted on TikTok, Jordan Nutter from the US, who posts under @anutterhomeloan, re-enacted a phone conversation she had with a client who was about to close on a property.The client had sent through bank statements for proof of deposit, the week before sheaposd had ,in her bank. However, when Jordan got the latest statement through, there was just , left in the account. Baffled as to where the money had all gone, Jordan called the client to find out what was going on. Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here.In the clip, she says: I got your bank statements you sent last night, I donapost understand what happened... all of the money is gone. I see all of these withdrawals and I donapost know what it is. Jordanaposs jaw then drops as the woman on the other end of the phone tells her she spent the money on a psychic. You called a psychic  We were supposed to have , in this account at least because thataposs what we needed and thereaposs , left, so how did we do this  Weaposre closing in a week so I donapost understand.  The woman on the phone goes on to explain that she called the psychic to seethe house was going to close. Jordan continues: But now all the moneyaposs gone  So have you talked to her about that, how itaposs going to come back  She said itaposs just going to happen  She has no idea where this money is coming from, that youaposre going to magically get in the next couple of days, that you spent on her to tell you that the house was going to close  Iaposm going to be honest with you, weaposre probably not going to close. We donapost have any money... you spent it all on her. More than one million people have since watched the clip, with thousands liking it. One person replied: Wait, so she really spent , on a psychic ! Jordan replied: It was bad, really bad. This makes me feel better about my le choices, said someone . A third wrote: Okay so my  impulse purchase on make-up from Sephora really isnapost that bad. But the psychic told me it will be fine, you are wrong, joked someone .Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. title: my pal told return gifts
story: My pal told me togts I bought her baby - the colour didnt suit herA woman took to Mumsnet to ask whether she was in the wrong to feel hurt that her friend asked her toa gt she bought for her baby - but the majority of users were on her side Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan |commentsA woman was left stunned after her friend told her tothe baby gts she got her because they didnapost suit the newborn. The anonymous woman explained that she gted her friend who had just had a baby some clothes.It was like a T-shirt and joggers set thing that I got in a small independent shop, she said in her post to Mumsnet.One of the items was a really pale pink and the other was a light yellow. But her friend was less than impressed with the clothes and was quick to text her to tell her so. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. Instead of thanking her for the thoughtful gt, which the woman admitted was not cheap, her pal told her the colours werenapost right and askedshe couldit. The woman was stunned and said she aposwould never have dreamed of making such a commentapos. I had some really unusual colours but I smiled, said thank you and the kids wore them as I was grateful to receive gts, she said. Sheaposs concluded her post by asking users where she has a right to feel offended. The majority of Mumsnet users were horried by the womanaposs rude reaction and a few others shared how they would respond to the text. aposNo problemyouthem I’ll get them refunded,apos suggested one person. Another added: She’s not a friend! Sorry, she was so rude to you but I think you’ve learnt your lesson now. I got a few sets of baby clothes that weren’t to my taste, added a third. I wouldn’t have dreamed of saying anything other than thank you. And they still got worn given that a small baby doesn’t really have an opinion on these things. A few people said they wouldnapost let the reason get to them, as one person said: I would rather something told me they didn’t like and I swapped for something  than they fake pretend they like and just dump in charity.Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: woman buys fancy velvet armchair
story: Woman buys fancy velvet armchair - but what arrives leaves her crying with laughterA woman has gone viral online after sharing her epic online shopping blunder, after purchasing what she thought was a stunning velvet armchair online, only to find out shed made a big mistakeMariam shared her shopping blunder Image: holyhijabi Tik TokByCourtney PochinSenior Audience Writer:,  Jan |commentsWhen it comes to online shopping, weaposve all been fooled by a deal that seemed too good to be true - and actually was.Weaposve recently seen how one woman spent £ on a dress online, but what arrived looked nothing like what she ordered. And now another woman has been duped by a stunning item she bought from a website.A TikTok user named Mariam, who posts under @holyhijabi, shared how she thought she had found herself a dreamy velvet armchair while browsing only - and it had free shipping! Amazing!However, she soon realised her blunder when the item was delivered to her home. Get the news you want straight to your inbox. for a Mirror newsletter here.In a viral video, Mariam, from New York, showed off a deep navy blue velvet chair, with ornate gold detailing around the back, arms and legs. The chair looks big enough to sit a person. However, the one she received turned out to be a tiny chair, possibly made as furniture for a dollaposs house. Mariam can be seen holding her hand over her mouth in the video in shock. She added a caption reading: This is why I canapost buy stuff... wait for it. Moral of the story, make sure everything you order is able.Thousands of people watched the video of the shopping fail, with it garnering over , likes and hundreds of comments.One person wrote: I was not expecting that. Why I have trust issues of ordering online, admitted another. A third asked: The real question is how much did it cost  It wasnapost cheap, shares Mariam. Someone  added: Thataposs just sad. title: dad carried away car bonnet
story: Dad carried away on car bonnet in bid to stop thief dies in hospitalIan McDonnell, , valiantly tried to stop the theft of his car in Clondalkin, Dublin, but was carried some distance and found lying in the road last Sunday" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _GettyImages-jpgth.jpg" width"" "" Gardai are investigating the death in DublinImage: NurPhoto via Getty ImagesByBradley JollyNews Wire:,  Jan |comments A dad who was carried on the bonnet of his car as a thief drove away has died of his injuries. Ian McDonnell, , was found on the road with le-threatening injuries at around .pm last Sunday, having been carried a signicant distance on the bonnet during the carjacking ordeal.He desperately tried to prevent the theft of his car, a grey Volkswagen Passat, at his business premises in Clondalkin, Dublin. Mr McDonnell died on Friday evening in nearby Tallaght University Hospital, Gardai said today. His we and children are being supported by police officers, Gardai added. A post-mortem will be carried out but officers continue to investigate the death.  The Volkswagen Passat was found in Greenhills, Dublin, on Friday and the recovered vehicle is due to be forensically examined. A second vehicle involved in the incident, a silver-coloured Toyota Aqua, which was stolen in Crumlin last Sunday, was found burnt out in Ballinascorney, Tallaght, on Tuesday. Gardai said this vehicle will also be forensically examined. Gardai in Clondalkin said they want to speak to anyone who was in the Robinhood Road area on the evening of January  between .pm and pm and who may have witnessed any activity which drew their attention, or who may have any video dashcam footage. Investigating Gardai said they are looking for any information on where either car was parked at any location, or whether either vehicle was seen in any petrol station or any other location over those days. Gardai are also seeking help from anyone who may have seen either of the cars in the areas of Ballymount, Walkinstown, Tallaght, Kylemore Road or Ballyfermot between .pm and pm last Sunday. Anyone with information is asked to contact Clondalkin garda station on  . story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Eveningcontent online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Courier. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Tayside and Fe. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Courier and the Eveningnewspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from The Courier and the Evening .Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access The Courier and the EveningePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to The Courier or the EveningePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on    Monday – Friday, am – pm, or email.Your subscription to The Courier will allow you to access all of the Eveningstories which are now available on The Courier website. title: new centre propels angus to forefront of farm innovation 2
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: ringlink issues a call for the next generation of farm workers
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. title: exclusive nicky walker talks trading football for the famous family shortbread firm
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. title: moray mum who shed seven stone during pandemic to scale britains three highest mountains
story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.When you purchased your subscription an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.Please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on  Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place. There are changes as to how you access your subscription benefits. See below, depending on what type of subscription you have.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through The Press and Journal website.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.There is no change to your reoccurring billing agreement. If you purchase a new subscription through The PJ website the price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription. If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team, on   Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The new website is now live. Evening Express content can now be found on The Press and Journal website.Your subscription will continue as normal and all your existing subscriber benefits will remain in place.You can access your ePaper on The Press and Journal website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Yes, we will still send you a daily ePaper reminder with a link to the Evening Express ePaper, every time there is a new ePaper available .No, the Evening Express ePaper app will remain exactly the same.If you are an existing Evening Express Web subscriber, you can log in to your account as normal through the PJ website here.If you have an ePaper subscription you can access your ePaper on the PJ website here.Or via a new link in your Daily ePaper email.Yes, your existing Evening Express login details work on The Press and Journal. To log in please visit www.pressandjournal login.If you have any problems logging in, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on  , or email.When you purchased your subscription, an email was sent to your account with your login details. To reset your password please use the following link.No, your existing reoccurring billing agreement will not change. If you cancel this agreement you can still purchase a new subscription in the future through The Press and Journal website. The price is subject to change and may be more than your current subscription.If you have any questions about your current subscription or how to access your subscription benefits in the future, please contact our Digital News Subscription Team   , or email.Please contact our Digital News Subscription Team on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.The Evening Express website is no longer available. If you navigate to the Evening Express website or have website links saved, you will be automatically redirected to The Press and Journal website.Yes. You will find all the content that you would have normally found at the Evening Express here.Our combined newsroom will deliver you all of the Evening Express content that you would expect from The Evening Express website, plus more! We will continue to bring you the very best local news, football insight and in-depth features, as well as your favourite Evening Express columnists. These can all be found on The Press and Journal website as well as live news # updated as it happens # breaking crime news and the latest from court. You can also find our very best content that was published originally on the Evening Express website. These articles will be marked as originally appearing on the Evening Express website.Some Evening Express content will be moved to The Press and Journal website. Your bookmarked links will automatically redirect to the corresponding page on The Press and Journal website.Yes, The Press and Journal and the Evening Express social pages will continue. We will curate content specically for our audiences through our Facebook, Twitter and Instagram channels. All articles will link to The PJ website.Your registration details that you set up on the Evening Express website will work on The Press and Journal website. Please log in to your account as normal via the top right hand corner of the website or with this link.If you have forgotten your login or password please click the password reset link and follow the instructions.Yes. All registered users can access  free articlesevery  days. Please note, this information is correct at the time of publication, however, DC Thomson reserve the right to change this in the future.No, you will no longer receive Evening Express branded newsletters. You will now receive Press and Journal newsletters. If you do not wish to receive these, click the #unsubscribe# link at the bottom of the newsletter email.The Press and Journal has a Web subscription available which will give you access to all content on site from The Press and Journal and the Evening Express. You can purchase a PJ Web or PJ ePaper subscription here: www.pressandjournal subscribeThe Evening Express ePaper subscription is still available for purchase here.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.No, there is only one Web subscription available on The Press and Journal. The Press and Journal Web subscription will give you access to all content on site from The PJ and the Evening Express. You can purchase a Press and Journal Web or Press and Journal ePaper subscription here.If you have an existing Evening Express Web subscription then all your subscription benefits are now available on The Press and Journal site. You have access to a bigger and better website, with all your favourite Evening Express content plus more.If you need help deciding what subscription is best for you, our Digital News Subscriptions Team are standing by to help. Please call on    Monday # Friday, am # pm, or email.You can purchase an Evening Express ePaper subscription here.Yes, you can. Our ePapers are an exact digital replica of the newspaper and carry unique content in both titles.
